clinical_study.brief_title: Progression of AtheRosclerotic PlAque DetermIned by Computed TomoGraphic Angiography Imaging(PARADIGM)
clinical_study.official_title: Progression of AtheRosclerotic PlAque DetermIned by Computed TomoGraphic Angiography Imaging(PARADIGM)

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Cardiology, Laranjeiras, Brazil
Weill Medical College of Cornell University

brief_summary.textblock: To describe the natural history of the coronary atherosclerotic plaque development and progression in mild to moderate CAD over time by CCTA with demographic and laboratory data for refinement of risk stratification of patients referred for CCTA.

detailed_description.textblock: All PARADIGM study patients underwent initial and follow-up CCTA based on order from their primary physician. Demographic data, targeted medical history, cardiovascular risk factors, and laboratory data was prospectively collected in electronic case report forms (eCRFs) at the time of the initial CCTA and at the time of follow-up CCTA.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in plaque volume and composition detected by follow up CCTA

secondary_outcome.measure: Unstable angina requiring hospitalization (yes or no)

study_pop.textblock: Study population is patients with suspected but not known CAD who had undergone serial CCTA by physician referral. Sites that had collected cohorts of CCTA patients with symptoms, risk factors, CCTA image data, and outcomes were invited to contribute data for a merged database. This sample includes patients with suspected but without known CAD, and asymptomatic subjects undergoing CCTA for risk stratification to evaluate the significance of changes in CCTA findings in different clinical contexts.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients underwent two or more clinically indicated CCTA with 64-detector rows or greater for CAD evaluation
- patients underwent at least 2 year interval between the baseline and follow-up CCTA
- No medical history of CAD at baseline
Exclusion Criteria:
- unavailable either clinical or laboratory data within 1 month from index CCTA or follow-up CCTA
- patients with prior revascularization before the index CCTA
- poor image quality of CCTA
